item.title: Ticket #627 (upgrade.php fails from 1.2.2 to latest 1.5 nightly) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
This call in line 1161 in classes.php seems to be where it fails(?)

Make a global instance. if (! isset($wp_rewrite)) {

$wp_rewrite = new WP_Rewrite();

it calls the init function (obviously) line 1129 which is where it seems to die for me:

function init() {

$this->permalink_structure =get_settings('permalink_structure');

So it's possible i'm editing this too often.... Traced some more and found in function get_alloptions() if i comment out $wpdb->hide_errors(); i get the following error:

WordPress database error: [Unknown column 'autoload' in 'where clause'] SELECT option_name, option_value FROM wp_options WHERE autoload = 'yes'

edited on: 01-06-05 19:44

item.title: Ticket #627 (upgrade.php fails from 1.2.2 to latest 1.5 nightly) updated
item.dc:creator: darryl
item.description:
i get the same error. I think i traced it to wp-settings.php where the line:

require (ABSPATH . WPINC . '/classes.php');

i.e. if i do this : require (ABSPATH . WPINC . '/functions-formatting.php'); require (ABSPATH . WPINC . '/functions-post.php'); echo 'got here';

I get 'got here'

if i do this: require (ABSPATH . WPINC . '/functions-formatting.php'); require (ABSPATH . WPINC . '/functions-post.php'); require (ABSPATH . WPINC . '/classes.php'); echo 'got here';

'got here' is never displayed....

item.title: Ticket #630 (pingback fails post due to sql error in xmlrpc.php) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #630 (pingback fails post due to sql error in xmlrpc.php) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
When a pingback is sent to a wordpress blog (verified through beta 2005-01-06), it fails with this error sent back to the blog that originated the ping via the already active http connection (this is from an ethernet dump):

<div id='error'>....<p class='wpdberror'><strong>WordPress database error:</strong> [You have an error in your SQ

L syntax near at line 1]<br />....<code>SELECT ping_status FROM wp_posts WHERE ID = </code></p>....</div><br />.<b>Fatal error</b>: Call

to undefined function: trackback_response() in <b>/usr/local/apache/htdocs/wordpress/xmlrpc.php</b> on line <b>1225</b><br />.

item.title: Ticket #629 (Creating link category with name of 'Content' causes links rendering ...) updated
item.dc:creator: thisgeek
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #629 (Creating link category with name of 'Content' causes links rendering ...) created
item.dc:creator: thisgeek
item.description:
If you create (or even rename) a link category to 'Content' without the quotes, it causes the rendering of the links on the main site to screw up.

I have posted some screen shots so you get the idea:

​http://www.midnightreign.org/wp-content/firefox_bad.jpg ​http://www.midnightreign.org/wp-content/firefox_good.jpg

and the same in IE

​http://www.midnightreign.org/wp-content/ie_bad.jpg ​http://www.midnightreign.org/wp-content/ie_good.jpg

item.description: With the latest nightly this is no longer an issue. Move to RESOLVED.

item.title: Ticket #628 (Lost Password Reset Failure + Disclosure!) updated
item.dc:creator: Giacomo
item.description:
Errata corrige: the current password is NOT disclosed, because the database UPDATE query fails (the password is NOT reset).

However, the user is emailed a new password which will not work.

item.title: Ticket #628 (Lost Password Reset Failure + Disclosure!) updated
item.dc:creator: Giacomo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #628 (Lost Password Reset Failure + Disclosure!) created
item.dc:creator: Giacomo
item.description:
Resetting a lost password fails, AND the current password is disclosed through a MySQL error:

====================================================== Database error: [You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near 'SET user_pass = MD5('9629e1') WHERE user_login = 'admin at lin] UPDATE SET user_pass = MD5('9629e1') WHERE user_login = 'admin' ======================================================

In wp-login.php, line 115

$wpdb->query("UPDATE $wpdb->users SET user_pass = MD5('$user_pass') WHERE user_login = '$user_login'");

should read:

$wpdb->query("UPDATE $tableusers SET user_pass = MD5('$user_pass') WHERE user_login = '$user_login'");

item.description: I'm currently running 1.2.2 with the Kubrick template. Today i tried to migrate to the latest 1.5 nightly. When i called upgrade.php after uploading the new files, i got a "fatal error: Call to undefined function: () in /xxxxxxxxx/x/xxx/htdocs/wp-admin/admin-functions.php on line 857" PHP error.

item.title: Ticket #622 (Add two-dialogue-box method for link) closed
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
90:

While you may be more used to two dialog box popups it is our opinion it is generally less usable than the current method. You're welcome to debate this on the wp-hackers list if you like.

As for inserting things where your cursor is, this is currently supported if your browser has the calls available for this to happen. We do it on every browser it is technically possible in.

item.title: Ticket #622 (Add two-dialogue-box method for link) updated
item.dc:creator: zealousagenda
item.description:
I can't answer you coding question, sorry.

But I would like the one-box-two-fields idea, as long as the scripting was smart enough so that if the second box (the linked text) was blank, it would insert the URL as a link with closed tags. Also, be sure the user can tab from one text field to the other... if you have a shortcut key assigned to link, and if you take my previous comment regarding the link being inserted where the cursor was last placed, then a link could be inserted without ever taking hands from the keyboard. That would be an innovation! I hope that it can be done.

item.title: Ticket #622 (Add two-dialogue-box method for link) updated
item.dc:creator: Adam_M
item.description: My JavaScript is rusty: could this be done with one dialog box that has two text fields?

item.title: Ticket #473 (Pings for future-dated posts should be sent at specified future date/time) updated
item.dc:creator: Adam_M
item.description: So a weblog author would need to log back in at some point to trigger the pings? Better than nothing, I suppose.

item.title: Ticket #473 (Pings for future-dated posts should be sent at specified future date/time) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: You can set up a cron job, but not everyone has that. So you could fake it, using PHP. Say, limit it to checking X times an hour, and then do Y and Z tasks when it runs. But probably best that it's tied to admin interface, so some unlucky viewer doesn't happen to be the one that triggers a boatload of trackbacks and pingbacks.

item.title: Ticket #473 (Pings for future-dated posts should be sent at specified future date/time) updated
item.dc:creator: Adam_M
item.description: Can't one do scheduled operations in PHP somehow?

item.title: Ticket #473 (Pings for future-dated posts should be sent at specified future date/time) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Hm... I think the way it works now is that it dynamically checks the date, and once the time has passed, the post shows up. There's no real activity. To accomplish this, we'd need to add a checker that checks to see if any dynamic posts have "come of age," probably through an admin hook. I don't think we want it to happen on a regular page load, as Pingback can sometimes slow things down.

item.title: Ticket #624 (xml reserved characters in urls cause invalid opml) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #624 (xml reserved characters in urls cause invalid opml) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
If a url in the link manager has a reserved xml character, it will cause the exported opml to be invalid xml.

& is the character I ran across, but I assume it is the same for all reserved characters.
